text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The response clearly explains the consent test, noting that tribunals must find consent in the BIT's dispute resolution clause or the rules. It specifically contrasts broad language (\"disputes concerning an investment\") with clauses limited to state obligations, citing *Urbaser v. Argentina* (which found consent in broad language) and *Roussalis v. Romania* (which rejected jurisdiction based on an asymmetric clause). This directly addresses the requirement of the criterion.", "criterion_id": "15177ed6-4514-4e8b-8f4f-02bf64fce179"}
